positive.review: Highly recommend, great game, very deep and engaging. Lots of strategy involved, great civilisation variety, prolific playerbase. As a former StarCraft 2 player, this game is so much fun. Much more relaxing to play casually and exciting to play competitively, but from all the things that stand out the most to me for what makes this game so great is its immersion, which is not something you expect out of an RTS. Not only are the graphics nice, but I absolutely love all of the decorative elements that generate (ie. small yards next to houses) that make the landscape constantly dynamic and interesting. From an immersion perspective, however, the decorative details pale in comparison to the expertly crafted audio experience. This game truly defines its own category of a S+ tier audio design. The background music for each civ, the gibberish units speak with accents based on civ(never gets old), the battle crys, the elephants and cannons, and the little cowbell sound when your scout finds a sheep. This game puts you in a different world and keeps you there.

I don’t play multiplayer at all, so the campaign is everything for me, and honestly, it’s more than enough. It feels like taking a history class, but in the most enjoyable and engaging way possible. The missions are fun, the storytelling is great, and the extra documentary-style videos are a fantastic touch that make the whole experience even richer. For someone who just wants a strong single-player journey, this delivers exactly what I hoped for.

It's essentially Age of Empires 2 but better. Civs are no longer carbon copies of each other and have unique elements to their playstyles (unlike Age 2 where every Civ was more or less the same with some units replaced with a unique unit). Generic unit models and buildings are also unique for civs which adds so much to the flavor of the game. For example, the generic archer has a unique model across the Mongols, Chinese, French, Abassid, Delhi, etc. You also no longer have the problem of, say, Chinese or Japanese sharing an "Asian" structure tileset (always bothered me how the Koreans in Age 2 had very Chinese looking buildings).

Although sometimes it is difficult to tell units apart in an army composition. For the most part units tend to look pretty similar to one another so I'm having to rely on the group selection icons at the bottom to isolate unit types.

As a long-time lover of Age of Empires II, I was excited when this was announced as a spiritual successor.

However, one single factor ruined it all for me - and, I think, for other "old" fans of the series: [b]competitive multiplayer[/b].
Everything in the game seems to be designed around competitive multiplayer, leaving single player as a pretty empty experience. 

Here's a breakdown of what contributes to this feeling.
- Everything is supposed to be fast. Don't keep the Town Center idle! Hotkeys! Get on with it! No more taking your time and building up a city, efficiency is all that matters.

- Single player savegames becoming invalid because of the new patch with the rebalances for multiplayer? You've got to be kidding me.

- Single player missions are pretty dull, repetitive and the tutorials basically explain you how to practice competitive multiplayer strategies.

- Units strategies are all based around very precise rock-paper-scissors like mechanics, but in "real" situations, well... more often than not it's just: build a big old army and throw it at the enemy. It all becomes a random messy melee anyway.

- Units aren't very characterized. In AoE II you could easily tell a Long Swordsman from a Two-Handed Swordsman, or a Pikeman from an Halberdier. They looked and felt like an upgrade, and they had few essential stats that made very clear how stronger they were. Now they are all like... parameters. Congratulations, you have upgraded your melee infantry! Now you have units that look the same and it's not entirely clear what has changed unless you're into hardcore competitive play.

- Same goes for buildings. They aren't really that recognizable, and the dull all-blue-and-gold UI doesn't help.

- One million uninteresting things supposedly made to maximise engagement for multiplayer. Bonuses, events, unlockables, XP points... a reflection of the social media era.

On the positive side, the short documentary videos about Medieval warfare are very nice and interesting... but that's pretty much all.

Old enough to call itself, "Anniversary Edition," and still feeling like an unpolished 1.0 release.

The quality of life features are what doom AoE4.  Or rather, their lack thereof.  Building a skirmish requires you to tab through multiple pages and hand configure everything, every game, because it resets everything to defaults instead of saving your previous settings.  A bunch of common functions, include Select Next Idle Villager, and Build Farm, do not have hotkeys and hotkeys for them cannot be set.  A lot behaviors that have been in the series since at least Age of Empire 2, back in 1999, are absent here, like Villagers understanding that only one of them can work a farm at time.

If this were an AoE clone, that might fly.  But this is a main line Age of Empires game.  The 2007 release of Age of Empires 3, as well as AoE2 Definitive Edition and Age of Mythology Retold all have features that this game is missing.

No single bad QoL is backbreaking, but they all pile up.  Converting your villagers from hunting to farming is something that was no big deal in any game except this one, where it's an APM nightmare.  Only being able to select all of your idle villagers at once is another thing that makes gameplay so much more difficult than it needs to be.

I really want to love this game, but it makes it so difficult.

• To start, you can save during the game, but it's pretty much useless since every update breaks save files. This alone is reason enough for a bad review.

• The gameplay is extremely different from previous titles, it seems to me like it is focused on seasons and super fast competitive multiplayer, rather than a more strategic growth and single player campaigns.

• Troops just do whatever they want, whenever they want. There are no stances like offensive or defensive; it is hard to control individual troops and seems like developers want you to just throw "everyone in" every time. The worst is the 'stand ground' because it only works once! If you move the troop, stand ground is turned off.

• Played the first campaign, it felt more like a documentary lesson/class rather than a map with goals where you are free to play. Spent half of the time watching cut scenes from a documentary with a monotonous boring narrator instead of playing (nothing like AoE2 videos, which I like and looked forward to).

• Then of course there is the whole civilisation variant thing, which feels like a lazy approach towards adding new civilisations. "Jeanne d'Arc" civilisation. Complete nonsense.

• I love the aesthetics of the game (except for the terrible interface, both in-game and menus), but half of the units and icons look the same, making it very hard to distinguish different types of units.

You have the pointless xp/level up and masteries, timed events and seasons, the awful and complicated UI, no game speed or pause (even for single player), amongst other things....

Sorry but cannot recommend it. Unless you are looking for the fast-paced e-sports send-all-men-to-the-battle-at-once type of thing, just go play any of the other 'Ages' games.
